title: Could smartphones become obsolete in the near future? - Quora

response.answer_text: Eventually they will likely morph into different solutions like wrist bands or Google Glass style devices. Their ability to perform without judgement on the end user will make it difficult for them to become obsolete though. Glasses and watches will both have fit factors but I will muse on this more below!! We may not see cell phone obsolescence until an even crazier solution comes like an implant or something. How and why wrist bands or glasses? Caveat: Technology will have to increase so these alternate solutions can compete with our consumer needs while fitting our weight and size needs etc. This is a hypothetical talk assuming we define the cell phone as a device that stays a flat black mirror going forward. Caveat 2: Virtual personal assistants will have to become much better so that alternate devices will have a similar or easier use without an input interface requiring our fingers, eyes, or both.  Caveat 3: air pods by Apple exist and they are amazing, they play audio, record your voice surprisingly well, while being mobile, rechargeable and simply a great product.  A similar product may need to be used to get the best experience out of our future alternate devices below.  Wrist watches are convenient, so is a personal assistant that can place calls, send messages, and write letters on your behalf while you dictate the message. The amount of screen that could fit onto your wrist could be just enough to allow a user to have a rather spartan alternate experience relying mostly on the digital assistant and the watch as a quick time/notification checker and miscellaneous status display interface. Also the wrist watch would be the backbone powerhouse that airpods connect to. Battery life, interface, and virtual assistant are the biggest issues I see here. If this future become more of a reality then some folks may become two watch consumer so they have no down time while one watch charges. Glasses are still bought worn and sold for various reasons despite LASERS! This futuristic device was already created by Google and it was a flop in the consumer market. It was before its time. The discussion about the product became a deeply tumultuous talk about privacy rights, and more. This style device has a lot of promise. The wrist watch style alternate described above takes a step away from cameras and screens being a big important and integral part of the device and use, thus described as a more spartan experience. The glasses can be more of a does it all solution, but glasses have a few concerns more over than the watch. They will be more susceptible to constraints regarding weight and size. They will also have more health and safety concerns. The glasses will eventually be able to provide a various degree of experiences though from a head up display to an alternate reality experience or possibly a full vr like experience, depending on retina projection technology advancements. BOTH? We could experience both of these alternates in the future with the wrist watch as a daily commuter style of device and the glasses being an entertainment style device, but who knows. This is something I have thought about as I like to tinker with end user products to better suit my needs, or discover products that perfectly fit my needs and this stuff is fun, but I need to move on from this question, for now.

Depends, Apple iPhones become obsolete simply because you can't install and update NEW apps because the older iPhones cannot get the software updates. It also depends on the battery.. when the battery dies, the phone is nearly obsolete unless you can get it replaced.. getting an iPhone X battery replaced by yourself is not easy nor cheap. Android phones last longer despite not getting new software updates, the app store will still allow the user to install new apps and update them, regardless of the OS version. As long as you take care of your phone, the phone will last decades. Phones nowadays are becoming “good enough” and many users are not buying new phones every year.

It was my first iPhone and is pretty much useless; unless I want to use it as a funky paper weight. It is obsolete, it is no longer manufactured or supported with updates. I now have an iPhone 8 which is still being made and supported. So I don’t think that smart phones will become completely obsolete and disappear all together. I think that they will just keep being updated, improved, and redesigned. As always…In my opinion.

This question is a good one, but a little imprecise. When talking about Smartphones you are actually talking about 3 distinct items packed together for the consumer. The Concept.The Technology.The Interface.Taking each item separately: The Concept - is probable going to keep being relevant for a long time.The Technology - has a built in 5–10 years obsolescence. So any smartphone bought today will probably be obsolete by 2030.The Interface - is a tricky question. Smartphones in the future may use4 the same form-factor 3–7″ color screen and single/dual finger interface, may use a hologram interface like in the “Minority Report” movie or be surgically implanted and use Direct-to-Mind interfaces. No way to tell.
